titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: S. Dexter, Dr: Kirkland, Mr: Holmes of Cambridge, Mr: Storer and Judge Davis, as a Committee of the Corporation and Overseers of the University, came this morning to give me notice of my being elected the professor of Oratory, on the foundation of Nicholas Boylston. I mentioned to them the impossibility, I should be under of performing all the duties assigned to the professor in the Rules and Statutes; and that I could neither bind myself to residence, at Cambridge, or to attendance more than a part of the year. They supposed that the Statutes might be so modified, as to accommodate me in these particulars; and requested me to state my own wishes in this respect to the chairman of the Committee in a letter, to which I agreed.— They went from here, after 12.— In the Evening with the Ladies I went to Captain Beale’s, where was a considerable Company— We came home about 9— Read Quinctilian Book 9. Blair’s Lectures 30–31. and Fléchier’s funeral Oration, on Turenne.

2. Day entirely at home— At length after an interval of two months we have a little, and a very little rain. In the afternoon I opened a couple more boxes of my books, but found scarcely any of those I want. My sister Adams and Louisa Smith, with my brother were here at tea. Mr: Coombs of Newbury-Port, and Mr: Harrod, a Cousin of Mrs: Adams, called, to see her; but made a very short stay— Read Quinctilian Book 10.— Juvenal Sat: 6. and 7.— Blair’s Lectures 32–33. and in the Evening the first Book of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, translated by Dryden—

3. Mrs: Black, Mrs: Blake and Miss Lamb called here this forenoon, but Mrs: Adams could not see them, being very unwell, after a bad Night. Mr: S. A. Otis called, on his return with his family from Plymouth— I went with him to my father’s, and took George from School, by the way— Dined at my father’s I had sent an apology to Captain Beale, with whom the club dined— The afternoon I pass’d in the Office, at my father’s— Walk’d home with George. Mrs: Adams was better this Evening— Extracts from Juvenal Sat 7— & 8— Began Quinctilian, Book 11. read but little; by means of interruption— Afternoon, read a Chapter of Aristotle’s Rhetoric, and part of Plato’s Gorgias, in Dacier’s translation— Evening— 2d: Book of Ovid’s Metamorphoses—translated by Addison— He neither soars nor sinks like Dryden. The Allegorical Figure of Envy, is horribly beautiful.

4. At length after a drought almost uninterrupted of eight weeks, there was last Night and this morning a plentiful and refreshing rain— I heard Mr: Blackburn at Church— There was public Service, at the Meeting House, though it remains unfinished— Eliza Johnson, spent the Evening at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s. I only read two of Sterne’s Sermons, and Blair, Lecture 34.

5. My brother was here a couple of hours this afternoon— Eliza Johnson, and Mrs: Adams rode out, with the children— In the evening, I went with the Ladies and spent an hour at Mr: Apthorp’s.— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 8. and compared Stepney’s translation with Gifford’s— The last though in some single lines inferior to his predecessor, is upon the whole much to be preferr’d— The fault of Stepney is feebleness—an occasional substitution of modern usages, for those of the original, and unnecessary paraphrase, in many passages instead of translation. I read the 11th: Book of Quintilian— And Blair’s Lectures 35–37.— The learning by heart of Les Racines Grecques is wearisome almost beyond endurance— Yet I do not give it up. The greater facility which I flattered myself with having attained, has again abandoned me— Or rather I find I learn much more easily some days than others, without any apparent cause for the difference.

6. Eliza Johnson went to Boston this morning with Mr: T. Greenleaf, and returned at Night— This afternoon we were at my father’s— Mr: & Mrs: Foster were there— I finished reading the Book of S. Matthew in the Greek Testament— And the twelfth and last Book of Quintilian— This work I purpose to read further, and in the original— I read also the first Book of Delille’s translation of Virgil’s Georgics.

7. Dined at my father’s— The Ladies were gone to Boston— In the Evening we had company at home— Afterwards walk’d.— Began to read St: Mark’s Gospel in Greek. Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 10.— Blair’s Lectures 38–39. I drew a meridian line yesterday and this morning in the window of my South-east Room. Wrote part of a letter to the Chairman of the Committee of the Overseers and Corporation of the College.

8. Mr: M’Guire a young Gentleman from Maryland came to me this morning with a letter of introduction from Mr: P. Morton— His purpose is to pursue the study of the Law here, in which he has already been engaged about two years, and he came to enquire whether I would take him as a student— Having no Office, and being out of the practice, I went with him at his desire to my brother— He could not however make his arrangements to his satisfaction— He dined at my father’s, and return’d to Boston in the afternoon— Dr: Waterhouse also dined at my father’s— The Ladies all went to Weymouth this afternoon— My brother & his wife went there to dine— I came home early this Evening— My reading and usual occupations were interrupted; so that except my usual occupation before breakfast, I only made short extracts from Juvenal Sat: 10. and read further in Plato’s Gorgias— The Phaedrus is without translation that I can find.

9. Mr: Barrett, and Captain Brackett called here this Evening and spent an hour— Walk afterwards with the Ladies. The warmth of the weather, and the desertion of our Servants had confined me at home the day through— Wrote to the chairman, of the Committee of the Corporation and Overseers of Harvard College.— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 10— Read Blair’s Lectures 40–43.

10. Dined at Mr: Apthorp’s with the Club— The meeting thin. Called afterwards at Mr: Cranch’s— In the Evening took a long walk to Braintree with the Ladies.— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 11. and read two books of the Treatise of Rhetoric address’d to Herennius, published with Cicero’s Works— But which are evidently not Cicero’s— I read them in a modern french translation.

11. Heard Mr: Blackburn at Church this morning— But a violent thunder-gust kept me at home, the afternoon. Mrs: Adams and Eliza went however to Meeting— In the Evening we walk’d up the Hill— I read Sterne’s Sermons 3. & 4. The parable of the Good Samaritan, and the Story of Nathan and David— Read also Blair’s Lectures 44–47. which concludes the Book.— We are still destitute of female Servants.

12. Weather again high beyond the standard of Summer heat— It has so continued almost two months. A warmer summer than I ever knew in this climate— But the Evenings have been and are yet very cool with few exceptions— This day I kept at home, the day through— Walk’d in the Evening with the Ladies— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 12. and 13.— Read the remainder of the Rhetoric address’d to Herinnius; and Walker on Elocution.

13. We had this afternoon a long and heavy thunder-shower— After it was over, I went with the Ladies down to my father’s— On the road we met my brother with William Smith my Sister’s Son— She arrived with him and her daughter Caroline this morning just before dinner— They brought a Son of Mr: King with them. Mr: Quincy was at my father’s this Evening.— I walk’d home, received a Letter & packet of German Books from Mr: Pitcairn— At the Brook this morning— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 13. Read the french translation of the introduction to the two Books of Cicero de Inventione— The translator has omitted the books themselves because he says they are substantially in the Rhetoric to Herinnius— Read also Walker on Elocution.

14. I went with my father this morning to Cambridge, and attended a meeting of the Academy of Arts and Sciences. Met W. Smith coming for me, as I was walking to my fathers— We took young King with us to Boston, and left him at Mr: Gore’s— Called at Judge Dana’s, and saw his Lady— The meeting of the Academy was well attended, but little business of Consequence done.— We dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Professor Pearson Mr: Steward the painter and Mr: Quincy were there— At 5 we left Cambridge— Called at Mr: J. Greenleaf’s, and return’d through Boston— I called at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s to deliver him a message from his son, and came home with Mrs: Cranch, whom I found at my father’s— Read nothing but the two chapters in the Greek Testament, finishing St: Mark’s Gospel, and my usual portion of the Racines Grecques.

15. George being unwell was confined at home— This afternoon I walk’d to my father’s, and return’d home early this Evening— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 13. & 14.— Began St: Luke’s Gospel in the Greek Testament. Read Walker on Elocution, and finished the Gorgias of Plato, translated by Dacier.

16. George still detained from school— This afternoon Mr: T. B. Johnson, came out from Boston with Mrs: Whitcomb, and were here at tea— We went afterwards to Mrs: Cranch’s, where my Mother & family were— My Sister, and brother’s wife had been here— We came home early— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 14. Read the Partitiones Oratoriae; the last french Translation— The translator does not give his name; but he is very conceited, Read also in Walker on Elocution— I have gathered some ideas from this work.

17. Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went in to Boston, and return’d this Evening with their brother Thomas— I took George to School, and at noon to my father’s where we dined. My brother and his wife were also gone to Boston— William Smith came home with me and George this Evening— Extracts from Juvenal Satire 14. and finished reading the Gorgias wrote a little this afternoon.

18. Heard Mr: Whitney; the Meeting-House being still under repairs, and unfinished— Mr: Shaw, who came from Boston to my father’s last Evening dined with us.— I went to my father’s this afternoon— Wrote notifications of the members of the Academy, elected in May last, and gave the letters to Mr: Shaw to forward. Walking home met the ladies and Mr: Johnson— I read scarcely any thing this day.

19. We all went down to my father’s this afternoon— I walk’d with Mr: Johnson, and took George, by the way. I came home alone, later than the rest of the family— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 15. and read Walker on Elocution.

20. Put out some young peach-trees of this years growth, and budded several peach and cherry-trees in my garden. This afternoon my mother, and Sister, with the family and my father were here— Mr: Johnson returned to Boston this morning— Extracts from Juvenal Sat: 16.—finished them— Finished reading also Walker on Elocution. Read a little of Lowth’s Introduction—and in the Evening, the third Book of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, translated by Addison— He has omitted about 20 lines, containing the names of Actaeon’s hounds

21. Great Summer heat again returned this day, after a short interval; and the drought continues. I went to my father’s and spent the afternoon in his Office— Read Cicero’s Topics, to Trebatius in the last french translation— Also began Lawson’s lectures on Oratory— My Mother and the Ladies with her went to Weymouth, and I stayed with my father, untill their return.— Began writing at home.— Read also Drummond’s translation of Persius. Sat: 2.

22— A very warm Night, and hot day— I walk’d this afternoon to my father’s alone, and returned in the Evening. Read a little of Persius Sat: 2. in the Original— Lawson’s Lectures on Oratory— Lecture 2–7.— Wrote a little. From the heat of the weather, nothing was to be done in the Evening.

23. Continuance of very warm and dry weather— It kept me at home, untill the Evening, when with the Ladies I walk’d to Braintree— Read Cicero de Claris Oratoribus, in the french translation, and Lawson’s Lectures 8–13— Also wrote a little in the morning.

24. We dined at my father’s, with Dr: Tufts and Mr: Cranch; and their families.— Finished the french translation of Cicero de claris Oratoribus, and in the afternoon read part of Court de Gebelin’s preliminary discourse, to his etymological dictionary of the Greek language— Also some pages of Valckenaer’s Manuscript, on the analogies of the Greek— These two authors in some respects agree— But they both reduce the roots to so small a number, that there might almost as well be none at all.

25. Heard Mr: Flint of Cohasset— At my fathers this afternoon— Part of the Evening at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s. Read Sterne’s Sermons 5. on the Story of Elijah and the widow of Zarephath, 6. On the parable of the Pharisee & the Publican— And 7— For none of us liveth to himself.— Also in the Introduction to the Origines Grecques— And Valckenaer’s Manuscript.— A recent occasion has made it necessary for me to give a redoubled attention to the subject of public speaking, both the theory and the practice— I therefore observed particularly Mr: Flint’s discourse, and propose to do the same in future, at all the public discourses I shall hear— Mr: Flint’s Sermon was on one text the whole day. Ecclesiastes 8.11.— He treated the subject ingeniously and methodically. His divisions naturally arose from his text, and his arguments were clear and forcible— His language, both in sermon, and in prayer was not merely correct, but elegant— He attempted nothing but to reason. His tone was wholly that of moderation, and his choice of hymns for singing, discovered judgment, and taste. With a good delivery he would pass for an uncommon preacher— Yet there is scarcely any man who appears in Mr: Whitney’s pulpit less popular. His defect is mere monotony, from two causes— 1. The want of proper inflexions in the voice, and 2. a pronunciation giving to almost every syllable the same quantity of time— He must have formed this habit, by too much anxiety to speak distinctly.— But it gives such a slow, drowsy a movement to his utterance, that it has all the appearance of excessive indolence, and is wearisome to every hearer— The faulty inflexions are common to almost all our Preachers; and all readers of written discourses are apt to fall into them— Mr: Flint has also in some degree the faults of the New-England pronunciation, consisting chiefly in giving to the vowels e and o occasionally Sounds which do not belong to them as benevelence, philosephy.—goodnoss pormitted, and the like— Sounding the u as oo, is a practice, which I apprehend will not soon be remedied, because my countrymen adhere to it upon principle.

26. Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went to Boston this morning, and returned at Night— I dined at my father’s. My brother was also gone to Boston, to meet his wife; who returned this day with W. Smith from their tour to Haverhill. I finished reading St: Luke’s Gospel in Greek. Began Cicero de Oratore in the french translation. read further, in Court de Gebelin’s introduction, and a chapter of Aristotle’s Rhetoric.

27. Walk’d to my father’s this afternoon, and returned home late in the Evening. Made arrangements for going to Commencement.— I began reading St: John’s Gospel in Greek.— Read also further in Cicero de Oratore, and Lawson’s Lectures 14–17.— Wrote but little.

28. Attended Commencement at Cambridge. The first time these twelve years. Mrs: Adams & Eliza Johnson. My Sister Smith, and her son and daughter— And my brother and his wife also went. We arrived just in Season, before the exercises began. Mr: Parsons persuaded me to take a seat next to him on the scaffolding above the Stage.— Professor Pearson presided— The performances of the young men candidates for the first and second degrees, were succeeded by the ceremony of conferring them— The whole was finished at about 3. O’Clock— I dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s; where I found Mrs: Jeffers— Mrs: Adams & Eliza dined at Mr: Chipman’s chamber, where they were invited by Captain and Mrs: Scott— My Sister & her children at Mrs: Guild’s.— My brother & his wife at Mr: Greenleaf’s.— After dinner, I called at Mr: Chipman’s, for the ladies. Between 5 and 6 in the afternoon we left Cambridge, and reached home at 8— Mr: Quincy brought home Eliza— My brother does not return untill to-morrow.

The performances of this day, were both in point of composition, and of delivery, much better than I expected. Taken altogether they were a very handsome specimen of public declamation— The young men all spoke audibly; many of them with gracefulness— Their language was in general correct; ornamented with the figures of which youth is peculiarly ambitious, and diversified, partly by the tone of serious declamation, and partly by attempts at humour; not always unsuccessful. The particulars in which it was susceptible
of improvement, appeared to me to be these.— 1. The subjects assigned to the candidates as themes of discourse, are not sufficiently diversified— There are two modes of declamation, which were altogether omitted, and which might be added to these exercises, with advantage— Panegyric; or an Eulogium upon some character distinguished in Ancient or Modern History. And Declamations such as those of the Antients, on some assumed state of facts— Critical parallels, between celebrated writers, are a third sort of subjects which might be introduced, and doubtless many others might be suggested. 2. The performers, did not sufficiently adhere to their subjects— This is a fault very general on such occasions; and proceeds from the comparative neglect of logical studies at the University.— There was a conference on the efficacy of Statuary, Painting, and History, in transmitting events to Posterity.— History was here put into strange company; to be degraded to such a level of competition— But scarcely a word was said about transmitting events— Each of the three conferees, spoke an eulogium upon the art, entrusted to his protection, passing some reflections upon the two others.— Another conference on the changes, produced in the State of Society, by the reigns of Constantine, Charlemagne, and Peter of Russia, became a mere personal panegyric on those Sovereigns. This to be sure was much the easiest way of performing the task; but if the subject assigned was above the powers of the speakers, a theme more suited to their state of knowledge should have been given, with injunction to keep close to it— In the forensic disputes, one party never undertook to refute the arguments of the other, but the speakers made each a disconnected disquisition, the one pro the other con— This may be one proper mode of discussion; but a true forensic ought to be a grapple of intellect between the speakers, a genuine image of real judicial litigation— There appeared to be no idea of method in the compositions of the speakers; and I certainly had no idea of methodical arrangement, untill long after I left College.— Of course they had no ingenious divisions of their subjects, and no artifice of construction in their discourse— As to the delivery— They spoke almost all of them too fast. A fault occasioned by the necessary limitation of their time, but which ought to be corrected— Many of them were very deficient in their memory, and required the prompter too frequently— I believe the exercises of Memory so much recommended by the antients is almost entirely neglected at this College.— Their pronunciation had the common errors of the soil— Confounding the sounds of the vowels—as form, for firm. Scorcely, &c—and elision of vowels as Nat’ral.— In the manner of speaking there was too much sameness— Some had the reading whine; and none had a just idea of accent, emphasis, or inflexion of the voice— The distinction of character between the Orators for the first and those for the second degree, was obvious as usual.

29. We all dined at my father’s— Mr: and Mrs: Peabody, and Dr: and Mrs: Welsh were there— This afternoon Mr: T. Johnson came out from Boston, with a french Gentleman, a Mr: Agasse, and Mr: & Miss Morris— They returned to Boston this Evening; he remained here. When I came home I found them gone— I read a little in Court de Gebelin, and a chapter of Aristotle.

30. Day at home— In the Evening we all took a long walk. I employed all my time in reading and writing, yet omitted much of my stated occupations— Read Lawson’s Lectures 18–21, on the Eloquence of the Pulpit; where I found almost the whole substance of what Blair says upon the subject— Indeed Blair seems to have borrowed from him rather too liberally, without making any acknowledgment.

31. Mr: Morris, and Mr: Agasse a french Gentleman, two of Mr: T. Johnson’s acquaintance, came out from Boston, and dined with us.— He returned with them this afternoon to Boston, and proposes to leave this part of the Country for New-York and Washington, next Tuesday. 3d.— William Smith also dined with us. In the afternoon we all walk’d down to my father’s— I barely finished reading the first of Cicero’s three Dialogues de Oratore, in the french translation.

Day. The general distribution of my time exactly as last Month.— The Racines Greques & Greek Testament, still engage my morning hours before Breakfast— Having finished Gedoyn’s Quinctilian and Blair, I now read in their stead the french Cicero, and Lawson— Walker on Elocution I have also gone through. I read occasionally at my father’s a Chapter of Aristotle, and other things miscellaneously; but all having relation to the same Subject— Write very little— Perceive as yet no progress in the acquisition of Greek.
